articleTopicPrompt: Please read the Grade 4 Unit of Inquiry poster. Then write exciting and fun kid's nonfiction article topics for 10 year old children related to the unit the student will be studying. You should write twelve topics for each of the lines of inquiry listed on the poster. Each topic should be surprising and have potential for the children to learn new concepts and facts.
articleTopics:
# Unit 6

## Problems and challenges that occur in our world

1. The Great Pacific Garbage Patch - How plastic trash swirls in a huge ocean vortex
2. Vanishing Rainforests - Exploring why the lungs of the planet are disappearing 
3. Thirsty World - How water scarcity impacts people globally
4. Climate Change - Uncovering the science behind Earth's rising temperatures
5. Endangered Species - Amazing animals on the brink of extinction
6. Oil Spills - The impacts of environmental disasters in our oceans
7. Poverty - How people live with limited resources around the world
8. War - Causes and impacts of conflict around the world
9. Disease - How illness spreads globally and impacts communities
10. Pollution - The toll dirty air, water and land takes on the planet
11. Hunger - Why food insecurity still plagues populations
12. Natural Disasters - Causes and effects of catastrophic earth events

## How individuals and groups have created positive change

1. Youth Activists - Kids making a difference in the world
2. Charities - Organizations tackling global issues 
3. Social Entrepreneurs - Businesses seeking solutions through commerce  
4. Forward-thinking Leaders - Pioneers of progress throughout history
5. Grassroots Movements - Regular people banding together to create change
6. Innovators and Inventions - New ideas and technologies that shape the world
7. Revolutions - When ordinary citizens stood up to power and transformed society
8. Conservationists - People dedicated to protecting animals and nature
9. Doctors Without Borders - Brave medical workers helping in crisis zones
10. International Aid - Countries assisting each other in times of need
11. Boycotts - Using purchasing power to protest injustice
12. Whistleblowers - Exposing wrongdoing at great risk

## My contribution to society

1. Volunteerism - Kid-friendly ways to help your community  
2. Reducing Waste - Tips for minimizing your environmental impact
3. Standing Up to Bullying - Creating a more positive school culture
4. Fundraising - Creative ideas for raising money for good causes
5. Using Your Talents - Discovering how your skills can help others
6. Being a Changemaker - Kids who changed the world and how you can too
7. Buying Responsibly - Making purchases that support people and the planet
8. Teaching Others - Share your knowledge to expand perspectives
9. Speaking Out - Using your voice against injustice
10. Protecting Nature - Simple acts to care for the environment
11. Saving Resources - Ways to conserve energy and materials 
12. Showing Compassion - Small acts of kindness that make a big difference
articleGenerationPrompt:
Write a 600 word, nonfiction leveled reading article in an exciting and fun style for 9-10 years old elementary students. The title of the article is "%ARTICLE_TITLE%". It's your job to write the rest.

Take it slow and review and, before you finish, edit the article to ensure that it has a fourth-grade reading level, about 900L, and the correct word count, 600 words. Be creative! Add some casual and kid-friendly language, but make sure to include lots of fun facts.

After that, include a glossary for 2-5 of the most difficult key words in the article. Finally, after the article write six multiple-choice reading comprehension questions about the article. Don't include the answers with the questions. The questions should get progressively more difficult. Be careful to tailor your questions to the level of the student. The questions should be multiple choice with 4 answers given. Include an answer key at the very end.

Use markdown formatting throughout. "Glossary", "Reading Comprehension Questions", and "Answer Key" should be second-level headings. Questions should be as a simple ordered list. There should be one blank line before and after each of the six questions. There must not be blank lines between the four answer choices. The glossary items should be as an unordered list without blank lines between the list items. Each glossary keyword should be in lowercase.
articleGenerationPromptB: Now rewrite the same article, glossary, questions for a third grade reader. The main body of the article should be around 600 words, not including the glossary, questions, or answer key. Don't change the title. Use markdown formatting throughout.
